snippet: Drugs that are normally used to increase focus are in some cases being prescribed simply to improve struggling, low-income students’ academic performance at school.
abstract: Some doctors are prescribing stimulants to low-income children who are struggling in elementary schools, not to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder but to boost academic performance; pediatrician Michael Anderson is a proponent of the idea, saying medication is the most reliable and pragmatic way for families that cannot afford behavior-based therapies to redirect the student toward success.
lead_paragraph: Drugs that are normally used to increase focus are in some cases being prescribed simply to improve struggling, low-income students’ academic performance at school.
